item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Christmas_tree, post:13, topic:484575”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=602809.msg4222563#msg4222563 date=1360847629]
Netty is better than MINA and IO imo, but it’s complicated as fuck
[/quote]

This.

ALSO, if you think that NIO is much better than io because it has new in front of it, you are mistaken. IO actually outperforms NIO on accepting and handling connections (last time I checked, may be different now )[/quote]

Define outperforms? If you have a separate thread for each connected client dedicated to simply processing incoming data, of course it will be better, but the overhead from each thread and having to switch between them will quickly start to take its toll.

Sure our hardware is getting better and better each day, but we still haven’t reached a point where we can effectively switch between large numbers of threads within short periods of time. In our case, up to a theoretical 2,000 connected clients per world, and all processing needs to be done well within the 600ms cycle.

Netty will perform better than Mina, hands down. (Remember, it was designed to!) But… there are still some things in Mina that I really like. Particularly, the session attribute map. Netty 4 made it a little better by including an attribute map with each channel, but they way you access them is still not as easy as in Mina.

Within RSPS's, which performs better under the circumstances. IO or NIO?

NIO (new IO) mainly because the non-blocking means you don’t need a separate thread for each connected client and it gives you buffers, file channel and lots of goodies that IO doesn’t.

item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

This tutorial shows you how to create a server starting from scratch! (Yes this is extremely easy, but this tutorial is aimed for people who don’t have as much knowledge about networking and what not!)

Note:

  • I will not show you Login

  • This is only partially network setup

  • You will need some java knowledge if you want to develop a server from scratch

  • Something’s may have not been explained; so please feel free to ask me about certain things, functions and any question you may have!

Introduction:
This tutorial will show you how to use NIO networking (library’s should already come with java) and setting up a basic client/source connection. You will however need to figure out how to get the client loaded up because some of the higher version servers usually have CRC, update server etc enabled so you will need to work it out.
I will only use 1 class file because the fewer the files the more easier it is to follow what is all does and it’s great for noobs

Difficulty: 3/10
Difficulty finishing off this guide to create a server for your own base on what ever version: 8/10

Recommended: Some basic Java knowledge!

Okay lets start off…

Start by creating your packages normally consist of domain.company.applicationName e.g. com.mopar.rs2, for the sake of this tutorial I’ll be doing com.rs2

First we need a main class that will run the server which includes all the start up process etc.
Create a new Java file called Server.java or Launch.java or anything similar to that.

Inside it you will need to declare the main body which is used to run the server.

it should look something like this;

[code]
package com.rs2;

public class Server {

public static void main(String args[]) {
	try {

	} catch (Exception e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}

}[/code]

You’ll be needing the NIO class’s, so just declare them as so under

public class Server {

add

	private Selector selector;
	private ServerSocketChannel channel;

These are needed so that the server knows what class’s the methods are being called from.

You now need a constructor for your server which will handle the connection.
Constructors are created like so;

[code]private Server() {

}[/code]

and then Server.java can be instanced.(Note: a private constructor cannot be instanced outside the class)

inside your constructor add;

		this.channel = ServerSocketChannel.open();
		this.selector = Selector.open();
		this.thread = new Thread(this);
		
		channel.configureBlocking(false);
		channel.socket().setReuseAddress(true);
		channel.register(selector, SelectionKey.OP_ACCEPT);

You will need to declare the Thread class other wise you would get errors appearing at this.thread = new Thread(this);
so under public class Server {
add private Thread thread;

You will notice that since we are using Thread you get errors. This is because we need to implement Runnable so that Thread class can execute a thread. You will
also need to surround the method with a catch exception because sometimes there may be a run time error due to a start up fault.

Your server class should now look something like this;

[code]public class Server implements Runnable {
private Thread thread;
private Selector selector;
private ServerSocketChannel channel;

private Server() {
	try {
		this.channel = ServerSocketChannel.open();
		this.selector = Selector.open();
		this.thread = new Thread(this);
		channel.configureBlocking(false);
		channel.socket().setReuseAddress(true);
		channel.register(selector, SelectionKey.OP_ACCEPT);
	} catch (Exception e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}

@Override
public void run() {
	// TODO Auto-generated method stub
	
}

} [/code]

Since were implementing Runnable you will need a run() method.

Inside the method add all this in;

@Override public void run() { while (true) { try { selector.select(); Iterator<SelectionKey> keys = selector.selectedKeys() .iterator(); while (keys.hasNext()) { SelectionKey key = keys.next(); if (key.isValid()) { if (key.isAcceptable()) { accept(key); } else if (key.isReadable()) { read(key); } } else { key.cancel(); } } } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } }

What this method does is accepts the connection from the client. When the Client connects to the server there will be a assigned key which the server reads which would determine if the server should accept the connection or refuse it.

You will need the accept(key) and read(key) methods so under the run() method add

[code]private void accept(SelectionKey key) throws IOException {
	ServerSocketChannel ssc = (ServerSocketChannel) key.channel();
	SocketChannel sc = ssc.accept();
	if(sc != null) {
		System.out.println("Connection received from: " + sc.socket().getLocalAddress().getHostAddress());
		sc.configureBlocking(false);
		sc.register(selector, SelectionKey.OP_READ);
	}
}

private void read(SelectionKey key) throws IOException {
	ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(2048);
	SocketChannel channel = (SocketChannel) key.channel();
	int status = channel.read(buffer);
	if(status == -1)
		return;
	//key.attachment().process(buffer);
}
[/code]

The accept(key) methods is basically accepting the connection and telling you that the key has been accepted by the client and it will print the IP address of the player trying to connect.
read(key) refer to http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/nio/channels/SelectionKey.html#isReadable()

When running the server you may find it helpful to have the server binded to the hosting port, this helps to stop multiple servers running at same time which could mess up the server.

add the bind() method:

	public Server bind(int port) throws IOException {
		channel.bind(new InetSocketAddress(port));
		return this;
	}

Now to finish off you would need to call everything you just created and make sure it is all running!

in the main method we created add new Server().bind(43594).start();
you will need to add the start() method which basically keeps the server running and not closing straight after everything has started up.

so add this method in:

public void start() { thread.start(); }

so your overall your Server.java will look something like this:


package com.rs2;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.net.InetSocketAddress;
import java.nio.ByteBuffer;
import java.nio.channels.SelectionKey;
import java.nio.channels.Selector;
import java.nio.channels.ServerSocketChannel;
import java.nio.channels.SocketChannel;
import java.util.Iterator;

public class Server implements Runnable {
	private Thread thread;
	private Selector selector;
	private ServerSocketChannel channel;
	
	public static void main(String args[]) {
		try {
			new Server().bind(43594).start();
		} catch (Exception e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
 	}
	
	public void start() {
		thread.start();
	}

	private Server() {
		try {
			this.channel = ServerSocketChannel.open();
			this.selector = Selector.open();
			this.thread = new Thread(this);
			channel.configureBlocking(false);
			channel.socket().setReuseAddress(true);
			channel.register(selector, SelectionKey.OP_ACCEPT);
		} catch (Exception e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
	}

	@Override
	public void run() {
		while (true) {
			try {
				selector.select();
				Iterator<SelectionKey> keys = selector.selectedKeys()
						.iterator();
				while (keys.hasNext()) {
					SelectionKey key = keys.next();
					if (key.isValid()) {
						if (key.isAcceptable()) {
							accept(key);
						} else if (key.isReadable()) {
							read(key);
						}
					} else {
						key.cancel();
						channel.close();
					}
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				e.printStackTrace();
			}
		}
	}
	
	private void accept(SelectionKey key) throws IOException {
		ServerSocketChannel ssc = (ServerSocketChannel) key.channel();
		SocketChannel sc = ssc.accept();
		if(sc != null) {
			System.out.println("Connection received from: " + sc.socket().getLocalAddress().getHostAddress());
			sc.configureBlocking(false);
			sc.register(selector, SelectionKey.OP_READ);
		}
	}
	
	private void read(SelectionKey key) throws IOException {
		ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(2048);
		SocketChannel channel = (SocketChannel) key.channel();
		int status = channel.read(buffer);
		if(status == -1)
			return;
		//key.attachment().process(buffer); // TODO: process player
	}
	
	public Server bind(int port) throws IOException {
		channel.bind(new InetSocketAddress(port));
		return this;
	}
}

Your server should start up successfully when you try to run it. When you try connect a client to it the server should print out the IP of the player trying to connect.

Hope you guys found this tutorial helpfull. If you have any question please feel free to post a comment below and DO NOT private messaging me/add my skype asking for help!

Explanation of what some of the code does! (information from java docs)

Runnable / public void run() : http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Runnable.html
Thread: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Thread.html
Selector: http://tutorials.jenkov.com/java-nio/selectors.html
ServerSocketChanne: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/nio/channels/ServerSocketChannel.html
SocketChannel: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/nio/channels/SocketChannel.html
SelectionKey (includes readable() and accept() : http://docs.oracle.comjavase/7/docs/api/java/nio/channels/SelectionKey.html
ByteBuffer: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/nio/ByteBuffer.html

Exception: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Exception.html
IOException: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/IOException.html

read() : http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/nio/channels/SelectionKey.html#isReadable()
accept() : http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/nio/channels/SelectionKey.html#isAcceptable()

bind(); binds the server to a specific port (stop multipul connection on the same port)
